config.question: Which of the following should Gerald Ford have avoided in the early days of his presidency to maintain public approval?

choices.content: granting Nixon a pardon after Watergate
appointing George H. W. Bush to the CIA
creating House and Senate overseers for the CIA

answer_3.response: After being president for only a month, on September 8, 1974, Gerald Ford shocked the nation by granting Richard Nixon a full and unconditional pardon for all federal crimes he may have committed. Some critics charged that Nixon and Ford had made a secret bargain; others pointed out how unfair it was for Nixon’s aides to go to prison while the chief criminal went free. Ford claimed he wanted to end the bitterness over Watergate, but his attempt backfired, eroding confidence in his leadership and linking him indelibly with the scandal.
